title: 108_hr4915
content: The "Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004" is cited as the short title. It introduces an exclusion for gain from stock of small, publicly traded companies in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004 excludes gain from the sale or exchange of section 1203 stock held for over 1 year for non-corporate taxpayers. The exclusion is limited to $100,000 ($50,000 for married individuals filing separately). 1203 stock refers to stock in a qualified small business C corporation acquired after the enactment date, under specific conditions. The Small Investment Tax Relief Act of 2004 excludes gain from the sale or exchange of section 1203 stock held for over 1 year for non-corporate taxpayers. The exclusion is limited to $100,000 ($50,000 for married individuals filing separately). 1203 stock refers to stock in a qualified small business C corporation acquired after the enactment date, with a market capitalization not exceeding $150,000,000. The amount of stock acquisition is determined by the closing price multiplied by the number of outstanding shares or based on the most recent amounts paid for each class of stock. The reporting period refers to the period for which the most recent annual or quarterly report is required to be filed with the SEC. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires filing annual or quarterly reports with the SEC. Aggregation rules apply, and additional rules similar to section 1202 are enforced. Conforming amendments include changes to section 642(c)(4) of the Code. Amendments are made to various sections of the Code, including 642(c)(4), 643(a)(3), 691(c)(4), 871(a)(2), and 1044(d). A new subsection is added to section 1202(b) regarding sales and exchanges under section 1203. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part 1 of subchapter P of chapter 1 of the Code. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part 1 of subchapter P of chapter 1 of the Code. The amendments in Section 1203 provide an exclusion for gains from stock of small, publicly traded companies. This applies to securities acquired after the enactment of the Act.
